sen.j: 野呂介石（のろ かいせき、延享4年1月20日 (旧暦)（1747年3月1日） - 文政11年3月14日 (旧暦)（1828年4月27日））は、江戸時代後期の日本の文人画である。
sen.e: Kaiseki NORO (March 1, 1747 - April 27, 1828) was a Japanese literati painter in the late Edo period.
Kaiseki NORO (March 1, 1747 - April 27, 1828) was a Japanese literati painter in the late Edo period.
Kaiseki NORO (March 1, 1747 - April 27, 1828) was a Japanese literati painter in the late Edo period.

sen.j: 紀州藩に仕え、祇園南海、桑山玉州とともに紀州三大南画家と呼ばれている。
sen.e: He served the Kishu Domain and has been called one of the three major Nanga painters along with Nankai GION and Gyokushu Kuwayama.
He served the Kishu Domain and has been called one of the three major Nanga painters along with Nankai GION and Gyokushu Kuwayama.
He served the Kishu Domain and has been called one of the three major Nanga painters along with Nankai GION and Gyokushu Kuwayama.

sen.j: 名前ははじめ休逸（きゅういつ）であったが、のちに改名して隆（りゅう）または隆年（りゅうねん）のふたつの名を混用した。
sen.e: His initial name was Kyuitsu, but later he renamed Ryu or Ryunen and used these two names mixed together.
His initial name was Kyuitsu, but later he renamed Ryu or Ryunen and used these two names mixed together.
His initial name was Kyuitsu, but later he renamed Ryu or Ryunen and used these two names mixed together.

sen.j: 字を松齢（しょうれい）、号 (称号)は介石のほかに班石（はんせき）、十友窩（じゅうゆうか）、澄湖（ちょうこ）、混斎（こんさい）、台嶽樵者（だいがくしょうしゃ）、第五隆（だいごりゅう）、晩年になって矮梅居（わいばいきょ）、四碧斎（しへきさい）、四碧道人（しへきどうじん）、悠然野逸（ゆうぜんやいつ）と号している。
sen.e: His azana (courtesy name) was Shorei and his second names were Kaiseki as well as Hanseki, Juyuka, Choko, Konsai, Daigakushosha, and Daigoryu, and also Waibaikyo, Shihekisai, Shihekidoujin, and Yuzen-yaitsu in the last years.

His azana (courtesy name) was Shorei and his second names were Kaiseki as well as Hanseki, Juyuka, Choko, Konsai, Daigakushosha, and Daigoryu, and also Waibaikyo, Shihekisai, Shihekidoujin, and Yuzen-yaitsu in the last years.

His azana (courtesy name) was Shorei and his second names were Kaiseki as well as Hanseki, Juyuka, Choko, Konsai, Daigakushosha, and Daigoryu, and also Waibaikyo, Shihekisai, Shihekidoujin, and Yuzen-yaitsu in the last years.

sen.j: 通称を弥助（やすけ）、後に九一郎（きゅういちろう）、喜左衛門（きざえもん）と称した。
sen.e: His common name was Yasuke, later he called himself Kyuichiro or Kizaemon.
His common name was Yasuke, later he called himself Kyuichiro or Kizaemon.
His common name was Yasuke, later he called himself Kyuichiro or Kizaemon.

sen.j: 紀州和歌山城下の湊紺屋町、町医 野呂高紹の三男として生まれる。
sen.e: Kaiseki was born as the third son of Kosho NORO, a town doctor of Minato Koya-machi near the Wakayama-jo Castle in Kishu Province.
Kaiseki was born as the third son of Kosho NORO, a town doctor of Minato Koya-machi near the Wakayama-jo Castle in Kishu Province.
Kaiseki was born as the third son of Kosho NORO, a town doctor of Minato Koya-machi near the Wakayama-jo Castle in Kishu Province.

sen.j: 10歳の頃より藩儒 伊藤長堅（蘭嵎）に儒学を学んだ。
sen.e: Around at ten years old, he started to learn Confucianism from Nagakata ITO (Rangu) who was Hanju (a Confusian scholar who work for a domain).
Around at ten years old, he started to learn Confucianism from Nagakata ITO (Rangu) who was Hanju (a Confusian scholar who work for a domain).
Around at ten years old, he started to learn Confucianism from Nagakata ITO (Rangu) who was Hanju (a Confusian scholar who work for a domain).

sen.j: 墨竹などの画を好み、中国の画法を独学しようとしたが進まず、14歳にて京都に出て黄檗宗 鶴亭（海眼淨光）について長崎派の画法を修める。
sen.e: He liked paintings such as ink paintings and tried to learn the Chinese drawing method, but failed, and at the age of fourteen he went up to Kyoto and learned drawing method of the Nagasaki School from Kakutei (Joko KAIGAN) of the Obakushu sect.

He liked paintings such as ink paintings and tried to learn the Chinese drawing method, but failed, and at the age of fourteen he went up to Kyoto and learned drawing method of the Nagasaki School from Kakutei (Joko KAIGAN) of the Obakushu sect.

He liked paintings such as ink paintings and tried to learn the Chinese drawing method, but failed, and at the age of fourteen he went up to Kyoto and learned drawing method of the Nagasaki School from Kakutei (Joko KAIGAN) of the Obakushu sect.

sen.j: 一旦郷里に戻るが再び上京し、21歳の時、池大雅について南画の技法を修得した。
sen.e: He once returned to his homeland, but went up to Kyoto again and mastered the technique of nanga (a school of painting originating in China).
He once returned to his homeland, but went up to Kyoto again and mastered the technique of nanga (a school of painting originating in China).
He once returned to his homeland, but went up to Kyoto again and mastered the technique of nanga (a school of painting originating in China).

sen.j: 京都と和歌山を行き来しながらおよそ10年もの間、毎日山水画十景を画くことを日課とした。
sen.e: He came and went between Kyoto and Wakayama and made it a daily routine to draw ten pieces of sansui-ga (Chinese-style landscape painting) every day for about ten years.
He came and went between Kyoto and Wakayama and made it a daily routine to draw ten pieces of sansui-ga (Chinese-style landscape painting) every day for about ten years.
He came and went between Kyoto and Wakayama and made it a daily routine to draw ten pieces of sansui-ga (Chinese-style landscape painting) every day for about ten years.

sen.j: 25歳のときには大雅の妻 玉蘭が和歌山を訪問している。
sen.e: When he was twenty-five, Gyokuran, the wife of Taiga visited Wakayama.
When he was twenty-five, Gyokuran, the wife of Taiga visited Wakayama.
When he was twenty-five, Gyokuran, the wife of Taiga visited Wakayama.

sen.j: 師を深く敬愛したが、28歳の時大雅を失う。
sen.e: He respected his master Taiga deeply, but permanently lost him when he was twenty-eight.
He respected his master Taiga deeply, but permanently lost him when he was twenty-eight.
He respected his master Taiga deeply, but permanently lost him when he was twenty-eight.

sen.j: このころ清の来舶商・画家 伊孚九に私淑し影響を受けている。
sen.e: Around that time, he looked up to Fukyu I, a trader and painter in the Qing dynasty, as his model and was influenced by him.
Around that time, he looked up to Fukyu I, a trader and painter in the Qing dynasty, as his model and was influenced by him.
Around that time, he looked up to Fukyu I, a trader and painter in the Qing dynasty, as his model and was influenced by him.

sen.j: 大坂の木村兼葭堂や紀州の先輩 桑山玉州とも親しく交流し画業の研鑽に励み、名を成すようになる。
sen.e: He closely associated with Kenkado KIMURA in Osaka and Gyokushu KUWAYAMA in Kishu who was his senior, devoted himself to his painting and become famous.
He closely associated with Kenkado KIMURA in Osaka and Gyokushu KUWAYAMA in Kishu who was his senior, devoted himself to his painting and became famous.
He closely associated with Kenkado KIMURA in Osaka and Gyokushu KUWAYAMA in Kishu who was his senior, devoted himself to his painting and became famous.

sen.j: 34歳の時再婚したが花嫁は17歳年下の士族の出身であった。
sen.e: He married again when he was thirty-four and the bride was from the warrior class and seventeen years younger.
He married again when he was thirty-four and the bride was from the warrior class and seventeen years younger.
He married again when he was thirty-four and the bride was from the warrior class and seventeen years younger.

sen.j: 終生を京都で過ごそうとしたが、藩命によって仕官することとなり46歳のとき紀州に戻った。
sen.e: Kaiseki wanted to live in Kyoto through life, but returned to Kishu when he was forty-six ordered by the domain for serving.
Kaiseki wanted to live in Kyoto through life, but returned to Kishu when he was forty-six ordered by the domain for serving.
Kaiseki wanted to live in Kyoto through life, but returned to Kishu when he was forty-six ordered by the domain for serving.

sen.j: 勘定奉行支配小普請として医業を以て藩に仕え、のちに銅山方なって領内各地を踏査している。
sen.e: He served the domain by medical practice as kobushin under kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance), later he became dozankata (in charge of copper mine) and surveyed in various places of the territory.

He served the domain by medical practice as kobushin (an organization of direct retainers of the shogun and feudal lords who obtain no more than 3000 koku) under kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance), later he became dozankata (in charge of copper mine) and surveyed in various places of the territory.
sen.cmt: kobushinの説明を括弧の中に追加しました。
sen.e: He served the domain by medical practice as kobushin (an organization of direct retainers of the shogun and feudal lords who obtain no more than 3000 koku) under kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance), later he became dozankata (in charge of copper mine) and surveyed in various places of the territory.

sen.j: 本草学にも詳しかったようである。
sen.e: It seems that he was quite familiar with herbalism.
It seems that he was quite familiar with herbalism.
It seems that he was quite familiar with herbalism.

sen.j: 江戸には2度赴いた記録があるが、晩年には江戸詩壇の大窪詩仏、菊池五山との交わりがあった。
sen.e: It is recorded that he went to Edo twice and associated with Shibutsu OKUBO and Gozan KIKUCHI of Edo poetic circles in the last years.
It is recorded that he went to Edo twice and associated with Shibutsu OKUBO and Gozan KIKUCHI of Edo poetic circles in the last years.
It is recorded that he went to Edo twice and associated with Shibutsu OKUBO and Gozan KIKUCHI of Edo poetic circles in the last years.

sen.j: その他に頼山陽、頼杏坪、篠崎小竹、田能村竹田、本居大平などの交友が伝えられる。
sen.e: It is said that he also associated with Sanyo RAI, Kyohei RAI, Shochiku SHINOZAKI, Chikuden TANOMURA, Ohira MOTOORI, and others.
It is said that he also associated with Sanyo RAI, Kyohei RAI, Shochiku SHINOZAKI, Chikuden TANOMURA, Ohira MOTOORI, and others.
It is said that he also associated with Sanyo RAI, Kyohei RAI, Shochiku SHINOZAKI, Chikuden TANOMURA, Ohira MOTOORI, and others.

sen.j: 1810年、大和国多武峰千手院に所蔵される黄公望の「天地石橋図」を臨模したことを多いに喜んでいる。
sen.e: He was with an intense enjoyment that he could copy 'Ame Tsuchi Shakkyo zu' (painting of the world stone bridges) drawn by Huáng Gōngwàng possessed in Tonomine Senju-in of Yamato Province.
He was with an intense enjoyment that he could copy 'Ame Tsuchi Shakkyo zu' (painting of the world stone bridges) drawn by Huáng Gōngwàng possessed in Tonomine Senju-in of Yamato Province.
He was with an intense enjoyment that he could copy 'Ame Tsuchi Shakkyo zu' (painting of the world stone bridges) drawn by Huáng Gōngwàng possessed in Tonomine Senju-in of Yamato Province.

sen.j: 公務で熊野三山の山中に分け入り、深山幽谷に数十日もあって山水の趣を体得したという。
sen.e: It is said that he went deep into mountains of Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha) due to public service and stayed for a few dozen days to learn taste of sansui (landscape).

It is said that he went deep into mountains of Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha) due to public service and stayed for a few dozen days to learn taste of sansui (landscape).

It is said that he went deep into mountains of Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha) due to public service and stayed for a few dozen days to learn taste of sansui (landscape).

sen.j: 画は人のためでなく己の楽しみのためとし、胸中に真山水を貯えれば、自ずと手が応じてるとして、写意のある画を求道した。
sen.e: He thought painting was not for other people, but for his own pleasure, and sought painting with shai (to express painter's spirit or target's nature) by thinking that true landscapes saved in his bosom would let his hand correspond naturally.

He thought painting was not for other people, but for his own pleasure, and sought painting with shai (to express painter's spirit or target's nature) by thinking that true landscapes saved in his bosom would let his hand correspond naturally.

He thought painting was not for other people, but for his own pleasure, and sought painting with shai (to express painter's spirit or target's nature) by thinking that true landscapes saved in his bosom would let his hand correspond naturally.

sen.j: 墨竹図・山水図を得意としたが、特に熊野山中を描いたものが多く那智滝は現在までに十数点確認されている。
sen.e: He was good at drawing bamboo groves and sansui-zu and especially draw mountains in Kumano area, and a dozen of paintings of Nachi Waterfall are authenticated by now.
He was good at drawing bamboo groves and sansui-zu and especially draw mountains in Kumano area, and a dozen of paintings of Nachi Waterfall are authenticated by now.
He was good at drawing bamboo groves and sansui-zu and especially draw mountains in Kumano area, and a dozen of paintings of Nachi Waterfall are authenticated by now.

sen.j: 兄と慕うひとつ上の桑山玉州とともに南画会の双璧と評されている。
sen.e: Kaiseki has been evaluated as soheki (a pair of matchless people) in the nanga (a school of painting originating in China) society along with Gyokushu KUWAYAMA who was one year older and respected by him like a brother.

Kaiseki has been evaluated as soheki (a pair of matchless people) in the nanga (a school of painting originating in China) society along with Gyokushu KUWAYAMA who was one year older and respected by him like a brother.

Kaiseki has been evaluated as soheki (a pair of matchless people) in the nanga (a school of painting originating in China) society along with Gyokushu KUWAYAMA who was one year older and respected by him like a brother.

sen.j: また長町竹石、僧愛石とともに｢三石｣とも称されている。
sen.e: Moreover, he is also called 'sanseki' (three Seki's) with Chikuseki NAGAMACHI and Monk Aiseki.
Moreover, he is also called 'sanseki' (three Seki's) with Chikuseki NAGAMACHI and Monk Aiseki.
Moreover, he is also called 'sanseki' (three Seki's) with Chikuseki NAGAMACHI and Monk Aiseki.

sen.j: 享年82。
sen.e: He died at the age of eighty-two.
He died at the age of 82.
sen.cmt: 年齢は算用数字で表記しました。
sen.e: He died at the age of 82.

sen.j: 法号 四碧院節翁介石居士。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name was Shihekiinsetsu Okaiseki Koji.
His posthumous Buddhist name was Shihekiinsetsu Okaiseki Koji.
His posthumous Buddhist name was Shihekiinsetsu Okaiseki Koji.

sen.j: 和歌山市吹上護念寺に墓碑がある。
sen.e: His gravestone is in Fukiage, Wakayama City.
His gravestone is in Gonenji-Temple in Fukiage, Wakayama City.
sen.cmt: 護念寺が抜けているので挿入しました。
sen.e: His gravestone is in Gonenji-Temple in Fukiage, Wakayama City.

sen.j: 四碧齋の号は、藩侯が彼の那智山図を見て嘆賞し「山色四時碧」の一行物を下賜したことを記念したもの。
sen.e: His second name Shihekisai originated from the commemoration that a lord of the domain praised his painting of the Nachi-san Mountain and granted Ichigyomono of 'Sanshoku Shihekisai'.
His second name Shihekisai originated from the commemoration that a lord of the domain praised his painting of the Nachi-san Mountain and granted Ichigyomono of 'Sanshoku Shihekisai'.
His second name Shihekisai originated from the commemoration that a lord of the domain praised his painting of the Nachi-san Mountain and granted Ichigyomono of 'Sanshoku Shihekisai'.

sen.j: 矮梅居の号は、仕官して2年目に賜った居宅に老梅があったことから。
sen.e: His another second name Waibaikyo originated from that there was an old plum tree in the residence given in the second year of his serving.
His another second name Waibaikyo originated from that there was an old plum tree in the residence given in the second year of his serving.
His another second name Waibaikyo originated from that there was an old plum tree in the residence given in the second year of his serving.

sen.j: 第五隆の号は、漢の第五倫の人となりを慕ったことから。
sen.e: His other second name Daigoryu originated from that he respected the nature of five human relations arranged in order in the Han dynasty.
His other second name Daigoryu originated from that he respected the nature of five human relations arranged in order in the Han dynasty.
His other second name Daigoryu originated from that he respected the nature of five human relations arranged in order in the Han dynasty.

sen.j: 三男だったが姉二人を入れると五番目の子であった。
sen.e: He was the third son, and the fifth child including two sisters.
He was the third son, and the fifth child including two sisters.
He was the third son, and the fifth child including two sisters.

sen.j: 和歌山県立博物館
sen.e: Wakayama prefectural museum

sen.e: Wakayama prefectural museum

sen.e: (1824) Wakayama City Museum

sen.j: 「呉仲圭詩意山水図」（1809年）静嘉堂文庫美術館 重要美術品
sen.e: 'Gochukei Shii Sansui-zu' (painting of the landscape expressed the intention of Gochukei's poetry) (1809), Seikado Bunko Art Museum, one of the important arts

sen.j: 「熊野三瀑之図」 （1812年）田辺市立美術館
sen.e: 'Kumano Sanbakuno zu' (painting of Kumano three waterfalls) (1821), Tanabe City Museum

sen.cmt: 年号が違うので訂正しました。
sen.e: Kumano Sanbakuno zu' (painting of Kumano three waterfalls) (1812), Tanabe City Museum

sen.j: 「歳寒三友図屏風」（1820年）田辺市立美術館
sen.e: 'Saikan no San-yu zu Byobu' (painting of the three friends in winter drawn on a folding screen) (1820), Tanabe City Museum

sen.j: 「紅玉芙蓉峰図」（1821年）和歌山 脇村奨学会
sen.e: 'Kogyoku Fuyoho zu' (painting of Mt. Fuji stained red by the rising sun) (1821), Wakayama Scholarship Foundation

sen.j: 「那智郡山図」
sen.e: 'Nachi Koriyama zu' (painting of Nachi Koriyama)
